title: In Zarda v. Altitude Express, Inc., will the Supreme Court rule that the Civil Rights Act of 1964 prohibition against employment discrimination “because of…sex” encompasses discrimination based on an individual’s sexual orientation?
preds:
Ouch. I was very wrong on this one. I need to go back to the drawing board.  My ideas were the following:  
1) the conservative majority would instinctively be against this kind of ruling; 
2) they would have ample room to rule against Zarda by refusing to expand the definition of "sex"
3) the crowd was on the wrong track because their opinion reflected a desired outcome rather than a probable outcome. In part I drew this conclusion because several very good forecasters who I respect had low estimates for this question as well.  So ... the first 2 of those ideas were clearly wrong, and not by a little bit. The third is untestable (at least in terms of the "why") but the bottom line doesn't lie: certainly the crowd was a lot more right than I was.  Lessons learned: 
1) it's often a good idea to err towards the crowd opinion especially in cases where I don't have a strong basis for my opinion myself
2) I didn't research the question beyond reading comments and a couple of news articles. I should err on the side of tackling fewer questions and researching them more
3) The ideas above aren't a methodical approach to answering the question and estimating a probability; but rather they are a "story" or scenario or hypothesis. That's a bad approach to forecasting. At a minimum I should have multiple credible hypotheses and attempt to assign probabilities to each

No it will not. A conservative court will determine discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation is not the same as discrimination based on sex because discrimination based on sex is limited to whether you are discriminated against because you are male or female. It also does not include transgender because gender is not sex.

Gorsuch reads the law literally and does not interpret what law writer may or may not have wanted in their minds. only a hail mary that the law as written is so vague that it could possibly included a broader reading may have a shot but so small I will stick with 0%
It seems to me that partisan split among Republican/Democrat lines is *the* deciding factor here.
I was wrong. They are more on the stick to the text and don’t deviate.

FantasySCOTUS crowd is at 52% [1]. Hedging my forecast towards the GJO crowd roughly a third given FantasySCOTUS's 70% historical accuracy rate [2]. [1] https://fantasyscotus.net/user-predictions/case/altitude-express-inc-v-zarda/
[2] https://www.lexpredict.com/portfolio/predicting-the-supreme-court/
They will delay decision due to covid 19
maintaining current forecast. Updating for passage of time.
maintaining forecast. updating due to passage of time.

The precedent is mixed but it ruled same sex sexual harassment is not allowed and thus recognized gay rights. 
Oncale v. Sundowner Offshore Services, 523 U.S. 75 (1998), was a decision of the Supreme Court of the United States. The case arose out of a suit for sex discrimination by a male oil-rig worker, who claimed that he was repeatedly subjected to sexual harassment by his male co-workers with the acquiescence of his employer. The Court held that the protection of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 against workplace discrimination "because of... sex" applied to harassment in the workplace between members of the same sex.[1]

I am of two minds. Under equal protection of  the law it seems they would rule for plaintiff. If the law did not say orientation they might rule the other way. Being it is a Conservative Court I am betting the later.

Department of Justice under President Trump filed briefs with the Supreme Court stating that Title VII protections do not extend to transgender and sexual orientation discrimination, confirming the Administration’s position on this issue. Under Obama legal rights were extended but both the Court and Administration are more conservative now. 5-4
Society is moving in that direction

This is one of those cases that makes my head hurt.  Zarda was this great guy who had a degree in IT, was a pilot, was a tandem jumpmaster and was a BASE jumper. Oh, and he happened to be gay.  When he did jumps with couples he would mention he was gay so the close physical proximity of tandem jumping wouldn't upset the boyfriend.    When the couple got home it came up that he was gay and the boyfriend calls and complains.   Zarda is fired.  There was no complaint at the end of the jump, no problem at all until the NJ man became aware Zarda was gay.  The firing was for ruining their experience,but there was no complaint until the subject of his homosexuality came up. He sued and then the case went up and down.  He was forced to a higher degree of proof and should have had different jury instructions and another trial. Everyone will try to skirt this one and there will be no justice in this case.  Zarda is deceased from a jump accident,  but other people could have benefited from this ruling.
Seeking cover for more conservative decisions.
Facts of this case are not good for the non-discrimination outcome.
Just dipping my toe in the water here. I don't have a strong feeling on this and I suspect that the crowd is about on the right track here.

Given the make up of the SCOTUS, especially considering the ideology of justices Thomas, Alito, Gorsuch, and Kavanaugh, I cannot see how the court opens itself to broadening the Civil Rights Act of 1964’s interpretation of “sex”.
Because the right-wing majority of the Supreme Court will vote against it.
Another 5-4 split between conservatives and liberals

Several of the court’s conservatives argued that expanding Title 7 to include discrimination against LGBT workers would be better handled by Congress. Attorneys for both sides have acknowledged that at the time the law was passed in 1964, its drafters likely did not envision that it would apply to gay or transgender individuals.
I'm thinking the court only took this case to set the precedent and clear the similar cases present and future from Dist. Dockets.
I don't think they will overturn lower Court.

https://ballotpedia.org/Altitude_Express_Inc._v._Zarda
Background Donald Zarda was a skydiving instructor at Altitude Express, Inc. In 2010, Altitude Express fired Zarda. Zarda filed a discrimination charge with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. He then sued Altitude Express in federal court, alleging he was terminated for his sexual orientation and arguing the termination violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[2][3] In March 2014, the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York granted summary judgment to Altitude Express, holding "Second Circuit precedent holds that Title VII does not protect against discrimination based on sexual orientation."[2][3] On appeal, Zarda petitioned the 2nd Circuit to revisit its interpretation of Title VII "in order to hold that Title VII's prohibition on discrimination based on 'sex' encompasses discrimination based on 'sexual orientation.'"[2] The 2nd Circuit, sitting en banc, vacated the district court's judgment on the Title VII claim and remanded the case for further proceedings. The 2nd Circuit affirmed the district court's judgment on all other claims.[3] Altitude Express petitioned the U.S. Supreme Court for review. In its petition, Altitude Express wrote, "Prior to the Second Circuit’s decision, the Seventh Circuit was the lone appellate court to hold that sexual orientation is protected as a form of sex discrimination under Title VII. See Hively, 853 F3d 339. These recent holdings are in conflict with every other Circuit that has addressed this issue."[4]
Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964         See also: Civil Rights Act of 1964 The Civil Rights Act of 1964 outlawed discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex or national origin in public places, employment and education. Click here for more information. Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 provides:
“ 	It shall be an unlawful employment practice for an employer . . . to fail or refuse to hire or to discharge any individual, or otherwise to discriminate against any individual with respect to his compensation, terms, conditions, or privileges of employment, because of such individual’s race, color, religion, sex, or national origin.[5] 	”

The 4 liberal justices will agree this is discriminatory, won't take much for at least one of the conservative justices (guess: Kennedy) to agree that the Civil Rights Act could not have predicted sexual orientation and will determine that sex discrimination includes sexual orientation  discrimination.  Truly religious outfits will  still not necessarily be inflicted as they can still hire based on the practicing religion of their employees and if they adhere to those tenants.
When title 7 was enacted homosexuality was criminal in some states.  I think the conservative majority will cite this fact as basis for not including sex orientation in title 7 protection.
Regardless of the moral merits of this position, it was not the intent of Congress in 1964.

Second Circuit is fairly liberal; at least on cursory inspection of political background.  The court may not want to rule on this, but I think there is a reasonable chance, if they did rule, that they would rule no.
